channel.title: Learning Java
channel.description:
Hello all, for the next few months I am going to attempt to learn java code.
After a bad experience with Cheezscape, (Couldn't even get it to work) I asked for help. People gave me strings of code that looked like total jibberish to me, and it didn't make sense at all. After that, I knew that to accually contribute to this community, I need to learn Java Code.
Anyways, I doubt I will be using Cheezscape, as I want to create something all my own. Yes, I have tried out different servers. To me, they all look like duplicates of Cheezscape with a different name, not to mention most of which were laggy pieces of crap.
I know this is a massive undertaking, but I don't want to have just another server that looks like a Cheezscape duplicate, with one cool feature.
If you guys could post sites that helped YOU learn java, that would be great. Any tips and tricks would be nice as well.
By the way, I have NO coding experience.

item.title: Learning Java
item.dc:creator: @Papa_Smurf Papa Smurf
item.description:
@Papa_Smurf wrote:

Yeah i’ve been looking in to it, still looks like jibberish to me. A lot of the guides say I SHOULD have coding/programming experience. Where should i start?

Read full topic

item.title: Learning Java
item.dc:creator: @Yogosun Yogosun
item.description:
@Yogosun wrote:

Well I have been doing java for about 3 years now. It’s similar to C# Syntax language.
Once you learn all the classes, objects, expressions, exceptions and maybe even swings if you become advanced enough it’s like speaking English.
Say it over in your head first on what you want it to do and how it should do it then translating it becomes natural.
It is one of the most advanced languages available, even more so powerful than C++ when it comes to networking.

For a beginner it’s not going to be easy but best of luck to you.

Read full topic
